The list was also published on the blog of my back then employer, but since the company doesn't exist anymore and their site is offline, I figured I might as well put it up here. entry.title: Information Overload 2010-09-26
entry.content:
Being sick this week I had a lot of time to read, but most if it went into Bruce Sterling's "Hacker Crackdown":http://www.mit.edu/hacker/hacker.html and Joe Dunthorne's "Submarine":http://www.amazon.com/Submarine-Joe-Dunthorne/dp/0241143969. Anyway, here we go:

  • "Did 'Star Wars' become a toy story? ":http://herocomplex.latimes.com/2010/08/12/star-wars-was-born-a-long-time-ago-but-not-all-that-far-far-away-in-1972-filmmakers-george-lucas-and-gary-kurtz-wer/
    I admit to being quite a Star Wars nerd, the "Han shot first":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_shot_first kind who pretends Episode I-III never happened and who actually sat through the entire "Holiday special":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Star_Wars_Holiday_Special. If you are remotely like me, this article providing some insider information by "Gary Kurtz":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Kurtz will be quite an interesting read.
  • "Computers and Mathematical Notation":http://www.jsoftware.com/papers/camn.htm
    Interesting thoughts on how programming languages (J in this case) could influence mathematical notation by Turing Award winner "Kenneth E. Iverson":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_E._Iverson
  • "Common Programmer Health Problems":http://sheddingbikes.com/posts/1281257293.html
    Some sane advice we all occasionally are guilty of ignoring.
  • "We Are All Talk Radio Hosts":http://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2010/08/we-are-all-talk-radio-hosts/
    On strawberry jam, reasoning and cognitive bias.
  • "The Millennium Development Goal that really does work has been forgotten":http://aidwatchers.com/2010/09/the-millennium-development-goal-that-really-does-work-has-been-forgotten/
    Sure, we'll help you. Just not in a way so that you eventually can help yourself.
  • "The Anthropology of Hackers":http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2010/09/the-anthropology-of-hackers/63308/
    Outline of anthropologist Gabriella Coleman's course about hacker culture at NYU.
  • "Ten things to look for in a circumvention tool":https://blog.torproject.org/blog/ten-things-look-circumvention-tool
    By Roger Dingledine of Tor fame.
  • "This Ain't Your Daddy's Wumpus":http://nostarch.com/download/Lisp08.pdf
    Example chapter from the upcoming book "Land of Lisp":http://nostarch.com/lisp.htm (PDF).
  • "In Arabian Desert, a Sustainable City Rises":http://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/26/arts/design/26masdar.html?_r=1&hp
    The first residents are starting to move into "Masdar":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masdar_City, a planned city built in Abu Dhabi. There seems to be some discussion about how much of a "real" city Masdar will be, but then Dubai didn't feel like a "real" place to me either, but more like a soulless agglomeration of skyscrapers and shopping malls.

entry.title: Information Overload 2010-09-05
entry.content:
• "Clojure or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Parentheses":http://nathanmarz.com/blog/clojure-or-how-i-learned-to-stop-worrying-and-love-the-paren.html
    Blog post explaining what draws the author - and many others - to Clojure.
  • "tactics, tactics, tactics":http://dlowe-wfh.blogspot.com/2007/06/tactics-tactics-tactics.html
    How to get better at programming. And chess.
  • "Die Sankore-Schriften":http://www.wissenslogs.de/wblogs/blog/die-sankore-schriften/wissenschaftsgeschichte/2010-08-19/die-sankor-schriften
    Little history of the Sankore university in Timbuktu, Mali (in German).
  • "The Making Of: Little Computer People":http://www.next-gen.biz/features/the-making-of-little-computer-people
    I love video game history, especially when it deals with games who influenced very successful titles later on.
  • "Sleep Deprivation May Spur Serious Mental Problems, Study Finds":http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-08-31/sleep-deprivation-may-trigger-mental-problems-in-young-people-study-finds.html
    A little reminder to all us geeks, nerds and hackers that sleep does play an important role in our overall well-being.
  • "Experience: I spent 29 years in solitary confinement":http://www.guardian.co.uk/lifeandstyle/2010/aug/28/29-years-solitary-confinement-robert-king
    Robert Kind who spent 29 years in solitary confinement for crimes he didn't commit talks about his experience.
  • "Why can you turn clothing right-side-out?":http://math.stackexchange.com/questions/2755/why-can-you-turn-clothing-right-side-out
    Math is everywhere.
  • "Brazilian agriculture:The miracle of the cerrado":http://www.economist.com/node/16886442?story_id=16886442&CFID=142315524&CFTOKEN=99196615
    Very interesting article on how Brazil transformed itself into one of the world's biggest food exporters.

entry.title: Information Overload 2010-08-29
entry.content:
• "How to feed the world":http://vimeo.com/8812686
    A nice 9 minute animation aimed mainly at kids. Interesting nonetheless and very well done.
  • "Danish volunteers build manned spacecraft":http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2010-08/23/danish-manned-spacecraft
    SomethingAwful goons will launch a space rocket on August 31st without government funding.
  • "Measuring the Speed of Light with Marshmallows":http://demonstrations.wolfram.com/MeasuringTheSpeedOfLightWithMarshmallows/
    A fun idea plus a Mathematica notebook for download.
  • "Inside the secret world of Trader Joe's":http://money.cnn.com/2010/08/20/news/companies/inside_trader_joes_full_version.fortune/index.htm
    Interesting insights into the "cool" convenience store chain.
  • "The 7 Stages Of Doing Something New":http://malevolent.com/weblog/archive/2010/08/27/7-stages-doing-something-new/
    A good reminder that "impossible is nothing" ;-).
  • "Maoists in Limbo":http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2010/08/26/maoists_in_limbo?page=full
    Article about the situation of Maoist revolutionaries in present day Nepal. I hope one of my favorite countries will soon be able to establish real peace!
  • "China's secure communications quantum leap":http://atimes.com/atimes/China_Business/LH26Cb01.html
    Overview of China's breakthrough in quantum communication. This could have interesting military implications (e.g. for submarines in the South China Sea), bet the PLA's very happy.
  • "Ruby for Awesome Command Line Applications":http://awesome-cli-ruby.heroku.com/
    Dave Copeland's presentation from "Lone Star Ruby Conference":http://www.lonestarrubyconf.com/. Not earth-shattering, but overall sane advice plus some useful links at the end.
  • "Badass of the Week: Nikola Tesla":http://www.badassoftheweek.com/tesla.html
    Entertaining little article on a very interesting person.
  • "Filesharing, Flattr und Bezahlschranken: Die Aufloesung historischer Unfaelle":http://www.neunetz.com/2010/08/25/filesharing-flattr-und-bezahlschranken-die-aufloesung-historischer-unfaelle/
    Value creation in the digital world and how it should differ from the analog times (German).

entry.title: Information Overload 2010-08-22
entry.content:
The web is full of wonderful information. In fact there's so much of it, it almost feels intimidating at times. I therefore plan to start a series of blog posts about articles/screencasts/lectures/etc. I enjoyed during the week (they may have been published at a totally different time though).

  • "The Philosophy of Punk Rock Mathematics":http://technoccult.net/archives/2010/02/25/the-punk-rock-philosophy-of-mathematics-technoccult-interviews-tom-henderson/
    An interview with Tom Henderson, aka "@mathpunk":http://twitter.com/mathpunk.
  • "Augmented Reality: The Nightmare Scenario":http://www.fastcodesign.com/1661871/augmented-reality-the-nightmare-scenario
    Short video by a Japanese architecture student about advertising in an augmented (hyper-)reality.
  • "The origins of abc":http://ilovetypography.com/2010/08/07/where-does-the-alphabet-come-from/
    Where does our alphabet come from?
  • "Beyond City Limits":http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2010/08/16/beyond_city_limits?page=full
    Is the age of nations over and are we entering the age of cities?
  • "Clojure 1.2 and Beyond":http://fogus.me/static/preso/clj1.2+/
    A presentation by "@fogus":http://twitter.com/fogus about the newly released Clojure 1.2. Covers everything that's important and has some wild speculation about the future too.
  • "Cauchy Curves":http://www.vector.org.uk/?vol=24&no=1&art=jonesreiter
    Drawing Cauchy curves with "J":http://www.jsoftware.com/.
  • "Digital copycats":http://mdn.mainichi.jp/features/news/20100820p2a00m0na019000c.html
    People in Japan are starting to digitize their books.
  • "Hydrogen bombshell: Rewriting life's history":http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg20727721.400-hydrogen-bombshell-rewriting-lifes-history.html
    Animals who don't need oxygen for survival.
  • "An Implausibly Illustrated Introduction to HTML5 Web Workers":http://wearehugh.com/public/2010/08/html5-web-workers/
    Exactly what the title promises.
  • "Urlaub ohne Ende":http://www.spiegel.de/unispiegel/jobundberuf/0,1518,711917,00.html
    Netflix employees can take as many holidays as they want. Working models for the post-industrial age? (German)
